Title: Proof of continuity of Thomae Function at irrationals.
AcceptedAnswer: Let $m=n_0-1$, so we want to consider rationals with denominators $1,\cdots,m$ in the interval $(b-1,b+1)$.  Since consecutive rationals with denominator k differ by $1/k$ and the interval $(b-1,b+1)$ has length 2, there are at most 2k rationals with denominator k in $(b-1,b+1)$. Therefore there are at most $2\cdot1+2\cdot2+\cdots+2m$ rationals in $(b-1,b+1)$ with denominator less than $n_0$, so we can choose a $\delta$ with $0<\delta<|b-r|$, where r is the rational with denominator less than $n_0$ in $(b-1,b+1)$ which is closest to b.
